central_thesis: The foundational importance of precise, shared terminological understanding is paramount for the accurate study and internal comprehension of Kabbalistic/esoteric concepts. Misinterpretation of key terms leads to 'alien perception' and 'blur[ring] the matter entirely,' hindering genuine spiritual progress and understanding.

structure_content.chapter_title: Part One: Table of Questions for the Meaning of the Words
structure_content.summary: This section serves as a comprehensive glossary defining 54 fundamental Kabbalistic and esoteric terms. Each entry provides a concise definition, often referencing specific internal sections of a larger, implied work (e.g., 'Part 1, Chap 1, Ohr Pnimi, 6'). The terms cover concepts of emanation (Ohr, Hitpashtut), vessels (Kli, Behina), divine attributes (Atzmut, Ein Sof), creation processes (Tzimtzum, Hidush), spatial/relational dynamics (Above, Below, Right, Left, Igul, Kav), and aspects of the soul (Neshama, Ruach, Rosh, Toch). The overall purpose is to establish a rigorous linguistic framework for advanced study.

key_concepts.definition: Every thing in the Olamot that exists as “existence from existence,” which is everything but the substance of the Kelim.
The will to receive in the Neʼetzal is called Kli; and the Shefa that he receives is called Ohr.
An Ohr that makes no discernment of degrees.
An Ohr that that is mingled with the Kli to the point of indiscriminating the Ohr from the Kli.
An Ohr that is Nimshach to the Neʼetzal in the first Hitpashtut, being the general sustenance and Atzmut of the Ne'etzal.
An Ohr that clothes the Ohr Hochma and Nimshach to the Ne'etzal at the first Hitgabrut.
It is Ohr de Hassadim before it is clothed in Ohr Hochma.
That which stems from its previous Behina.
This is the name of Behina Dalet in Ein Sof. She is named after her unification with Ohr Ein Sof.

The Ohr Elyon that expands from His Atzmut is One and as Pashut as His Atzmut. As it is in Ein Sof, so it is in Olam Assiya, without any change and addition of Tzura whatsoever, and that is why it is called One.

The name Creator relates solely to the actual Hidush (innovation, novelty), meaning the “existence from absence," which is the substance of the Kelim, defined as the “will to receive” in every essence. It was necessarily absent from His Atzmut prior to creation.
It is Hishtavut Tzura that brings the spirituals together and attaches them to one another, while the Shinui Tzura departs them from one another.
When there is no discernment whatsoever among the four Behinot of the will to receive it is said that they are even and equal.

Ohr that stems from the Maatzil to the Neʼetzal is called Hitpashtut of Ohr. In fact, the Ohr Elyon is not affected in any way by that. It is like lighting one candle from another, when the first is not lessened by it. The name only indicates the reception of the Neʼetzal.
Behina Aleph in the will to receive is regarded as more Zach than the three Behinot that follow her.
It is a certain sum of Behinot that hang down from one another and are mingled with one another by an order of cause and consequence, such as days, moths and years.
Behina Dalet in the Ratzon, which does not receive the Ohr Elyon inside her by the power of the Tzimtzum, is regarded as the Shoresh of the darkness.
It is the Ohr of the Atzmut of the sustenance of the Neʼetzal.

Behina Dalet of the Ratzon that became empty of Ohr is regarded as darkness compared to the Ohr. With respect to the Kli she is regarded as a Halal because Behina Dalet was not deprived from the Neʼetzal in its Atzmut by the Tzimtzum, but there is an empty Avir in it, without Ohr.
When speaking of a relationship of cause and consequence of the Neʼetzalim, we express the cause by the term “Before” and the consequence of that consequence by the term "After.”

Unique indicates the Ohr Elyon that shines and rules all the various degrees in their different forms to the extent that it makes them equalize with His unique Tzura. Unified indicates the end of that rule, meaning after He had already equalized and brought their Tzura to be as unique as He is.
Two different Behinot that have equalized with one another in their Tzura unite into one.

Sometimes, an inferior degree ascends to an equal level with the superior, when the superior needs her for her own completion. In that state, the inferior is regarded as the “left” and the superior as the "right."
The title "Maker” relates specifically to the pouring of the Ohr into the Olamot, which means everything but the substance of the Kelim.
The will to receive in the Ne 'etzal is the Kli.
Hishtavut Tzura of the inferior with the superior is a “rise above."
Any cause is regarded as the Maatzil of the effected degree. The title Maatzil contains both the Hamshacha of the Ohr and the Kli that receives the Ohr.

The will to receive that was imprinted in the souls is what separates them and “severs” them off of the Ohr Elyon. That is because it is the Shinui Tzura that separates in spirituality. The issue of the origin of the Neshama refers to the transition between Olam Atzilut and Olam Beria, which will be explained in its place.
The one of a lesser virtue is regarded as being “below."

Unique indicates the Ohr Elyon that shines and rules all the various degrees in their different forms to the extent that it makes them equalize with His unique Tzura. Unified indicates the end of that rule, meaning after He had already equalized and brought their Tzura to be as unique as He is.
It is the will to receive that is necessarily there.

Meaning from Behina Aleph to Behina Dalet. Behina Dalet that was left without Ohr is regarded as being “below” all the other degrees. The frailer the will to receive, the higher one is considered to be. Therefore, Behina Aleph is regarded as the "highest” of all.
Where there isn't any want whatsoever, and where an addition to the completeness that exists there cannot be conceived.
The more important is regarded as “Above,” and the worse as “Below.”
The will to receive in the Neʼetzal is the “Place” for the Shefa and the Ohr in it.
It is a degree that consists of all four Behinot of the Ratzon.
It is a degree with only the first three Behinot of the Ratzon.
If the Shinui Tzura of the degree from the Shoresh is not so apparent as to separate from the Shoresh, it is regarded as “touching” the Shoresh. The same applies between each two adjacent degrees.
This is the name of Behina Dalet in Ein Sof. She is named after her unification with Ohr Ein Sof.
The Sof and the Sium of every Neʼetzal is done by the detaining force in Behina Dalet, where the Ohr Elyon stops shining because she does not receive it.

When there are no discriminations of above and below among the four Behinot of the will to receive, it is considered as an Igul (like a round picture in corporeality, where up and down are indistinguishable). Because of that, the four Behinot are called circular Igulim one inside the other, where it is impossible to distinguish up from down.
It is the more important.
Two degrees without any Hishtavut Tzura on any side are regarded as completely separated from one another.
This is a place that is prepared to receive Tikun and wholeness.
Where there are no discernments of degrees and sides.

One who conquers one's desire. In other words, one who detains oneself from receiving and does not receive despite one's great desire to receive, is regarded as restricting (performing a Tzimtzum) one's desire.
Indicates a discernment of up and down that was not there before. It also designates a much frailer Heʼarah than before.
The closer one's Tzura is to another, the closer they are considered to be.
That part in the Neʼetzal that is the most like the Shoresh is called Rosh.
Ohr Hassadim is called Ruach.
Where there are no discernments of degrees and sides.
The Holy Names are descriptions of how the Orot that they imply are attained. The name of the degree designates the conduct of attainment in that degree.
One who receives inside is regarded as the Ohr being measured and limited in the Kli. However, one who receives outside is not regarded as placing any Gevul on the Ohr that one receives.

Any Hidush Tzura is regarded as a spiritual movement, for it is separated from the previous Tzura and acquires a name of its own. It is like a part that is separated from a corporeal object that moves and exits its earlier place.

practical_system.description: While not a grimoire of external rituals, the text prescribes a rigorous internal practical system for intellectual and spiritual development. The core 'practice' is the systematic memorization and deep comprehension of esoteric terminology. This mental discipline is crucial for internalizing the precise mechanics of emanation, contraction, and the interaction of Lights and Vessels within the spiritual worlds. By preventing 'alien perception' and ensuring conceptual clarity, this foundational practice enables the practitioner to accurately map and navigate the subtle realities described, forming the cognitive groundwork for any subsequent magical or meditative work. The text underscores that accurate intellectual apprehension is a prerequisite for effective spiritual operation.
tools: The 'Table of Questions and Answers' (the glossary itself)

relevant_quotes.text: Note: Forgetting the meaning of a word regarding some issue is worse than erasing that word from the issue. This is because the alien perception would blur the matter entirely. Hence, accustom yourself through the Table of Questions and Answers, until you can answer them by heart without trouble.
The will to receive in the Neʼetzal is called Kli; and the Shefa that he receives is called Ohr.

The name Creator relates solely to the actual Hidush (innovation, novelty), meaning the “existence from absence," which is the substance of the Kelim, defined as the “will to receive” in every essence. It was necessarily absent from His Atzmut prior to creation.

One who conquers one's desire. In other words, one who detains oneself from receiving and does not receive despite one's great desire to receive, is regarded as restricting (performing a Tzimtzum) one's desire.

critical_analysis.relevance: This glossary is a foundational text for students engaging with sophisticated Kabbalistic systems, particularly those related to the Lurianic tradition. It provides precise definitions for core concepts such as Ohr (Light/Emanation), Kli (Vessel/Will to Receive), Tzimtzum (Contraction), Hitpashtut (Expansion), and various Behinot (States/Discernments). The emphasis on exact terminology directly addresses a critical challenge in esoteric study: maintaining conceptual integrity amidst abstract and often metaphoric language. Its relevance lies in preventing the 'alien perception' the author warns against, ensuring that practitioners can build a coherent internal model of the spiritual worlds and their operative principles. It serves as a necessary primer for understanding the energetic flows, structural principles, and developmental stages within the Tree of Life and the Olamot, thereby underpinning any practical magical or meditative work rooted in Kabbalah.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience consists of serious students and practitioners of Kabbalah and Hermetic Qabalah, particularly those delving into Lurianic texts (e.g., 'Etz Chayim,' 'Talmud Eser Sefirot'). It is designed for individuals who require a rigorous, standardized, and internally consistent understanding of the complex lexicon to engage deeply with the system's philosophy and operative mechanics, rather than those seeking a superficial overview.
